editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A tragedy called all's lost by lust.
Divers times acted by the lady Elizabeth's servants. And now lately by her majesty's servants, with great applause, at the phoenix in Drury lane.
Quod non daunt proceres, dabit histrio:

list.item: Julianus, a general against the Moors: father to Jacinta.
Antonio, a don, lover of Dionysia, yet husband to Margaretta.
Alonzo, a don, father to Dionysia:
Pedro, an old fellow, father to Margaretta:
Jaques, a simple clownish gentleman, his son, personated by the poet.
Lothario, a Privado to the King.
Lazarello, minion to Antonio. Cob a page.

div.head: The argument.
div.p:
Roderigo, King of Spain, being deeply enamoured upon Jacynta, a beautiful young Spanish lady, daughter to a great commander in the wars, (Called Julianus) hath often by private solicitations and gifts, tried to win her to his embraces; but they not prevailing, he resolves to enjoy her by force: whilst he sails in these lustful thoughts, Lothario, (A gentleman of better fortunes than condition) is his pilot, steering his wickedness on. To help which with wind and weather, Mulymumen, King of Barbary, with an army of 60000. Moors, is ready to cross into Spain, to invade Roderigo, who no way frighted, but laying hold on this occasion, sends Julianus as general against the African, and by his two evil spirits, Lothario and Malaena) gets access to the lady in her father's absence, but their engines breaking, he ravishes her. The dove being thus ruffled, is delivered out of one falcon's talons, to the gripe of another:
Lothario is made her keeper, whom Jacynta one day finding fast asleep, takes the keys of the castle from him, and flies to her father in the camp; who hearing the story of the ravisher, joins with those Spanish lords in his army, to be revenged on the tyrant: to hasten this vengeance, the African is taken prisoner, and again set at liberty, with condition that he shall rally all his scattered troops, and then those two armies being incorporated in one, to drive Roderigo out of his kingdom, and to enthrone the Moor there. Mulymumen so likes the ravished lady, that he begs her of her father to be his: but Roderigo flying into Biscany, and the African lord of all, is scorned by Jacynta, who in revenge, calls for Julianus (Her father) commanding his eyes to be put out, and her tongue to be cut out, and so to lead him; in the end, the barbarian to shorten Julianus his misery, gives him a weapon, the Moor hath another, with intent to run full-butt at one another, much entreaty being made to let Jacynta die nobly, 'tis promised, and then they both being ready to run, the Moor snatches Jacynta before him, and so the father kills his own daughter, and is presently by the Moor slain himself.

Antonio marries Margaretta, fair, but low
in fortunes, and coming to these wars, falls in love with Dionysia, daughter to Alonzo, but the women come to tragical ends, and Antonio for upbraiding Julianus with selling his King and country to the Moor, is by Julianus slain.

lg.l: Thus from the poet am I bid to say,
He knows what judges sit to doom each play,
(The overcurious critic, or the wise)
The one with squint, tother with sunlike eyes,
Shoots through each scene: the one cry as all things down,
Tother hides strangers faults close as his own.
'Las! Those who out of custom come to gear,
(Sang the full choir of the nine muses here)
So carping, not from wit, but apish spite,
And feathered ignorance, thus our poet does slight.
'Tis not a gay suit, or distorted face,
Can beat his merit off, which has won grace
In the full theater, nor can now fear
The teeth of any snaky whisperer:
But to the white, and sweet unclouded brow,
(The heaven where true worth moves) our poet does bow;
Patrons of arts, and pilots to the stage,
Who guide it (Through all tempests) from the rage
Of envious whirl winds. O do you but steer
His muse this day, and bring her to th' wished shore,
You are those Delphic powers, whom she'll adore.

div.head: Actus primus.
div.stage: Enter Rodericke, King of Spain, Lothario, Medina, Julianus, Antonio, and Lazarello.

sp.speaker: Rodericke.
sp.l: Give leave: Lothario.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: My sovereign.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The news in brief: how replies Jacinta?
Will she be woman? will she meet our arms
With an alternate roundure? will she do?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nothing to the purpose my liege, cold as Aquarius,
There she was born, and there she still remains;
I cannot move her to enter into pisces, I
Laid the flesh to her too, and the delights thereof, she leans
Another way, and talks all of the spirit, I
Frighted her with spirits too, but all would not do:
she drew her knife, pointed it to her breast, swore
She would do something, but women's tongues are
Sometimes longer than their arms.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Enough, we have bethought another way.
This wooing application is too mild:
'Tis better trust the mercy of a storm.
To haste our way, than to be calmed for ever,
Short of the wished haven:
Now draw near, you told us of a hot invasion ▪
The barbarous and tawny Africans,
Intend upon our confines.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: True, my liege.
Full threescore thousand are descried in arms,
Ready to pass the straits of Gibraltar,
Whose watery divisions, their Afric bounds
〈…〉 om our Christian Europe in Granado,
And Andalusia; they spread and flourish
Their silver moons, led as it is supposed,
By some blind guide, some saintish infidel,
That prophecies subjection of our Spain,
Unto the Moors.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: They would deter us with their swarthy looks:
Were they the same to their similitude,
Sooty as the inhabitants of hell,
Whom they nearest figure; cold fear should fly
From us as distant as they are from beauty:
They come to sacrifice their bloods to us,
If that be red, a mere rubrum,
We'll make so high to quench their silver moons;
And on their carcases an isthmus make
To pass their straits again, and forage there.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your forward valour speaks you majestical,
But my dread liege, does not your treasury
Grow thin and empty? so long have you held
A champion resolution 'gainst the Turk ▪
That Spain is wasted in her noble strength,
On which presuming, 'tis to be supp 〈…〉
The Moor is thus encouraged.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And yet we undaunted Julianus, our treasury is
A mine unscorched, we have a castle
Supposed enchanted, we'll break the magic,
If spells there be, open the forbidden doors
Which twenty of our predecessors have refused,
But added each a lock to guard it more,
Rather than our soldiers shall want pay
To fight our battles nobly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O my lord, that's a dangerous secret, only known
To such as can divine futurities,
And they with fearful prophecies predict
Fatal events to Spain, when that shall be
Broke up by violence: till fate hath run
Her own wasting period; which out stayed
Auspiciously they promise, that wreathes are kept
In the foredooming court of destiny,
To bind us ever in a happy conquest.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Tut. fear frights us not, nor shall hope fool us
If need provoke, we'll dig supply through hell
And her enchantments. Who can prefix us
A time to see these incantations loosed?
Perhaps 'twill stay ten generations more,
When our blood royal may want succession,
If not; what boots it us (Lost in our dust
And memory 500. years) that then this hidden
Work shall be; tush, the weakness of our predecessors
Shall not fright us, all is not deadly,
That looks dangerous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wish no life to see that day.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Nor I, so many Kings have feared that destiny.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Lord Julianus, we commit to you
The charge of this great work against the Moors,
With title of lord general, as you please,
Order this high affair; call to the field
An equal army against those Africans,
The bold and hardiest soldiers of our kingdom ▪
Scourge back again these halfnaked infidels
Into their sunburnt climate; in thy heart
be loyalty and courage, strength in thine arm:
With christian valour strike the heathens dead,
And for thy triumph, bring the mulyes head.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This honour which your majesty has given me,
Though better it might fit another's wearing,
Of abler limbs, where time has not defaced,
Nor half so many winters quenched his blood,
As a new spring it hath revived again
This autumn of my years; there's but one care
I leave behind me within the court of Spain,
My poor Jacinta, mine, and only mine;
May she here thrive in honour, and in favours,
And I shall meet her with a victory,
(Heaven put before) as shall endow us both
In your high esteem.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That shall be our care noble Julianus, to see her safe,
We love Jacinta more than you must know,
And for her sake we do remove you hence;
You may thank your daughter for this honour sir,
If you knew our purpose.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I understand all this, whilst he wars abroad, his
Daughter must skirmish at home; Venus is in conjunction
With Mercury, wit and lechery are both in labour
At once alas poor maidenhead, thou'rt cast i'faith,
And must to execution; virginity hadst thou been
Moulded in my compass, thou hadst 'scaped this pitfall.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: On, to thy charge, prosper in thy high deeds;
Who aims at honour nobly, nobly speeds.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My heart and tongue, thus sentence to my fate,
In honour thrive, in baseness ruinate.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: All help him on his speed: Lothario.
sp.stage: Exeunt omnes nisi rod. And Loth.
sp.l: Have we not finely moulded our design?
Time's ancient bawd, opportunity attends us now,
And yet our flaming blood will scarce give leave
To opportunity.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I told your highness of a second bawd to time, and yet
Not times second neither, for time ne'er patterned her
a thing real, not a dumb moral, as time itself
Is, but a speaking thing, and one that speaks
Effectually; one that has wracked more maidenheads
In Spain, than she has years upon her reverent brows,
And yet she writes odd of threescore, an odd wench 'tis.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thou namest her to me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Malena.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And hast instructed her?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I have prepared her fit for instruction my liege; she
Waits her further confirmation from your highness:
O every soldier has a double heart, when the king's in field.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Call her

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: By her right name; bawd, where art thou bawd?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: If words will serve, if not, by rapines force;
We'll pluck this apple from th'hesperides.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: This is the thing I told your highness of.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: A reverent one it is, and may be called schoolmistress of her sex; if Apelles had ever pictured forth experience, here might he take his pattern.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Indeed my liege, I have been the pattern that a great
Many has taken out pictures by, I confess I have
Been a greater friend to the hospitals, than the nunneries,
And I think it was the greater charity, because
They are the poorer, and more wretched places.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: The very ipsissima of her sex, my liege, as old as
She is, I will undertake she shall wrestle a fall
With the strongest virgin in Spain, and throw her down too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thou must be my lawyer (I'll fee thee well,)
And at the bar of beauty plead a cause,
Which whether right or wrong, must needs be mine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Indeed in rightful causes, weak lawyers will
Serve turn, but the wrong had need have
The best orators; I'm but a weak vessel, you
Know my liege.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: She'll hold out I warrant, hark you my liege,
this vessel is not hollow yet, it does not sound,
There's mettle in her, there's sack in this tun,
That has eaten up a great deal of dead
Flesh in her time, lights, longs and bad livers.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Come, come, you must not plead an insufficiency.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: I'll do my best my lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Tush, in malo consilio foeminae vincunt viros.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Does he not abuse me my liege?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Not at all, he says women overcome men in
Giving counsel.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is there not a faulty word amongst them?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Thou art able to corrupt any good sense, with bad construction:
I say foeminae vincunt, that is, quasi vincere cunctos,
Overcomes all men.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Go to, go to, there is a broad word amongst 'em, vincunt
Quotha, is it spoke with a K, or a c? but in plain
Language I will do my best, if she be of my sex, I
Will show her the end of her function, men follow
The traditions of their forefathers, so should
Women follow the trades of their fore-mothers.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I see thou hast persuasive oratory.
Here's juice of liquorish, good for thy voice,
Speak freely, and effectually.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I will speak the words that have o'erthrown a
Hundred in my time.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I was within compass then.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Let me have access to her, if she be flesh and blood,
I'll move her, I will not leave her till I turn her to a stone.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Unite your forces both, conquer in love,
I will reward as for a victory
Purchased with blood from my worst enemy:
Effect, for ill things have their effects we see
Prosper, we'll call it a prosperity.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You'll bring me to the place and party?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Prepared with all advantage. I will assist thee, thou
Destroyer of maidenheads.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Your passions err my lord, did you foresee
What may ensue; folly begets danger,
Nay oft, their full effects, destruction;
You would not clothe the nobleness of your blood
In such base weeds, she's a beggar you dote on.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou'st spoke the worst thy malice can invent,
A beggar say'st? and better being so,
If a small star could overshine the sun,
And show his brightness in the solstice,
Should it be blamed or praised? the feeble vine
Brings forth sweet fruits, whilst the cedars's barren;
Beggar is she, I'll poise her graces with't,
And see how many infinites she'll pull
The balance down, and yet that poverty
A goodness disesteemed, she's fair,
Modest, lovely, wise, virtuous.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Nay, if you dote, I'll waste no more good counsel,
And what's her dower sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Infinites, I named them to thee.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: O she's fair, a fair dowry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Chaste and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Those are jewels indeed, but they'll yield little.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They are not things of prize, they are far off,
And dear, yet ladies send not for 'em.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: May not a league be taken for a time?
Defer this hasty match, you have employment
As a soldier, the King has given you charge,
Approve your champion valour in the field,
If that remove not this domestic trouble,
Retire upon your Venus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll prevent that venom,
This night I will be married to my sweet,
And then her memory enjoyed, shall strengthen
Mine arm against my foe, which else would droop,
Suspecting of her loss, I fear it now;
what eye can look upon her, but is captived
In the enchanted prison of her eyes.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Why you'll be jealous in your absence then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away, away, thou dost forget her virtues
Faster than I can name 'em; she's chastity
Itself, and when a shrine shall be set up
Unto that saint, it shall be built upon
The marble that shall cover her.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Here comes the general.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No more, no more, thy fears are all follies, my Jacinta

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I must not leave you thus.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Antonio? what unplumed? you are a soldier sir,
And soldiers should be forward; look ye
I have bright steel for the black Africans;
I tell you sir, I went not with more joy
Unto my maiden bride, that Hymen night,
From whence I fetched this jewel of my heart,
Then now I do unto my second nuptials.
O 'tis a gallant mistress, an old man
Is young again at sight of her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Worthy sir, your leading valour will centuple the hearts
Of all your followers; when set you forward?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tush, we limit time to her best haste,
Three days will be the most, the longer stay
Loses the more advantage.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We shall be ready to attend your honour,
Hymen, this night I vow to thee, Mars be my
Morrow's saint.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Here were a saint fitting your orisons.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Blasphemy, speak that no more, the beggar,
(If you will so profane to speak her so)
Is gold refined, compared unto this rubbish,
Diamond to marble; my noble lord
We'll leave you to hasten our attendance on you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Farewell Antonio,
I'm in haste too, my preparations call me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I call too, I beseech you hear me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thou'rt a clog to me,
Methinks thou shouldst be reading o'er new fashions,
Conferring with your tirewoman for fair dressings,
Your jeweller has new devices for ye,
Fine labels for your ears, bracelets for wrists,
Such as will illustrate your white hand;
These are all pedlars beware to me, Jacinta;
I am for corslets, helmets, bills, bows, and pikes,
The thundering guns, trumpets tan tara,
The rattling sheepskin, and the whistling fife:
What music's this to your ears? ha, farewell,
Farewell, and heaven bless thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Good heaven, how slightly
You o'errun my fears, you go to meet
With a full power, an armed foe abroad,
And leave me single to an enemy
That hath both power and will to ruin me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis treason that thou speak'st, and by the saint
Of Spain, mend it, or I'll discover thee:
Wrong my dread liege, my King, my sovereign,
To say that he should dote upon your face,
Away, away, 'tis but your beauty's pride,
So to belie itself thou art not fair,
Thou hast no eye to attract majesty,
To look upon't; say he speak love to thee,
'Twas but to try thee, perhaps 'twas my consent,
Will you inquire the hidden hearts of Kings?
He would not wrong thee for his kingdom's wealth,
Even for my sake, away you wanton fool.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: There has been ravishers, remember Tarquin.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There has been chaste ladies, remember Lucrece:
I'll hear no more, my time and haste hath barred me,
My blessing take, heaven and that shall guard thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You leave me in a tempest, heaven guide my fate,
O let me sink ere I be captivated.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I do not like this match, this gay outside
Is cloth of gold, within a ragged lining.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: O poor comparison father, do they use to line cloth of gold with cloth of gold; no, but with fine, gentle, and easy linings, and such my sister may be, for though I say it that should not say it, my sister has a good face, a white neck, and a dainty hand, and that may serve for lining for the best cloth of gold in all Spain.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Cedars and shrubs cannot grow up together.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Away, away, speak not so like a wood monger, I'll
Put you down with a caparison now, do we not use
To graft sweet apples upon crabtree stocks, do we
Not use to inoculate your malicatoon upon a gooseberry?
Such is my sister's case now, say that the noble man
Would inoculate his lordship upon my sister's yeomanry,
What hurt were in this? would it grieve you to be a
Lord's brother, or this old woman to have her lady
Daughter to ask, gravam, how do you, will you ride
Abroad in your croarch, or your embroidered side-saddle?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ay, thou talkest wildly boy, yet errest not much
In my conceit, be content man, and add as meet it is,
Joy to content, your daughter shall be made a happy woman
By a noble marriage.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Happy say'st thou? o 'tis as distant as the moon from earth,
And has the like effects, it changes oft,
So with a silver brow, greatness looks on us
Promising and lovely, but once grown full,
It brings swelling billows to o'erwhelm us.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Pray father talk no more of the moon, but of your son,
Not myself that am your son and heir, but of your
Son in law that shall be, my noble l. Antonio, lord of
Barcelona, and his noble lady my sister, that shall be.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: 'Twill well become her, what arms shall I give to make her gentle by?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Those we can buy of the heralds, you know she
has cried oranges the most of her time here in civil,
Now a fine orange for her crest, with civility
Written round about it would speaks wondrous well,
Than a capon in a scutcheon with a gizzard
Under his left arm, with his spurs upon his heels
Riding upon a leman.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Away, away
Thy talks impertinent, what should a capon
Do with a leman?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Ay, you say well father there indeed,
A capon desires no leman, and therefore
We'll hope of both that neither the lord
Prove himself a capon, nor my sister a leman.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ay, this thou touchest by a forced figure,
The perfect sense of all, thence grows my fear:
This love was first 〈◊〉, and born in lust
How long has he laid an unlawful liege
Against her virgin honour, which had she yielded,
And been so lemond, she ne'er had been proffered
The style of wife.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Peace, see they come.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I marry, here's a lady now will wear her own hair.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay now no further protestations,
You have said enough to make me new, or ruin me,
And this my spirit, bids me prophesy
If you repent, as love might be o'er sated
In its best desires; and any cross event
Should fall upon this your unequal choice,
Yours is the crime, your handmaid must be blameless,
Since you have sought what I have not desired,
And yet, you may avoid the fatal doom
(If any such there be) by throwing back
Your achieved vassal.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Teach me no error.
I will not learn it, sweetest, if you do.
Speak nothing now but of those holy rites
Whose sacred hands must guide us to the path
Of your desired joys.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here's all the bar;
When these have given consent I am your own.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It shall be done in this acknowledgement.
Father and mother let me but call you so.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And brother eke also.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes brother too,
By this I claim them all, your daughter makes
Me your son, and yours.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And my brother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll not forget that neither.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: If you do, I will forget to call your lady sister.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, I have questioned all the will in me,
And find it now resolved unto your wish.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: You have my good will too brother.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Mine is wrought out through rocks of doubt and scare,
She is your own, I send her pilots like
Into an argosy beyond her steerage.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll hand the helm with her, and there abide
Safety, or drowning.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: She will be hated when the disdainful brows
Of noble greatness shall be shot against her,
The scorns and flouts she shall endure, will be
Fa 〈…〉 less content, then is the humble quiet she enjoys.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All those I will rebuke, and if she blush,
The beauty then will check their painted cheeks
With a rebounding shame upon themselves,
Let not more obstacles be mentioned,
Only let privacy protect us yet
Although we scant the full solemnity
Due to thy wishes; Hymen which afterwards.
Shall dare the largest blazon.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Call it mine sir,
And then the smallest ceremony may serve.
All wants, are only wanting unto you
To give your greatness the due ornaments.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shall your kind pains provide us of a priest,
Whom my instructions shall direct you to.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Shall I? why who am I pray?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, good brother do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O you teach me sweet; yes good brother do.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O as a brother I will, I perceive these great men
Are some what forgetful of their poor kindred.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A friar in saint Augustine's monastery
Ask for one Benedick, my commends to him
Will bring him with thee, he's prepared for it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'll be the clerk myself for the groat's sake,
Which you know will arise out of the two and twenty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tush, I'll triple that wages.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Nothing grieves me but this wedding will be so still born
We shall have no dancing at it, but I'll foot it
To the priest howsoever, fala, la, la, la:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Howe'er the King's employment in the wars
Calls on my person, I shall leave behind
Myself in thee, and bear myself along
In thy sweet memory.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O sir, you speak of swift divorce.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Relish to joy, a breathing from our pleasures,
Come, come, true love shall tie two hearts in one.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O happy prove.

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Come old reverence, if ever thou hadst music in thee,
To inchant a maidenhead, now strike up.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You play well
On the Pandora, sir I wonder your skill.
Fails to make her dance after it.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Tush, I give thee
The precedence, wire strings will not do't, it must be
A wind instrument that's governed with stopping of holes,
Which thou playest well on, my old viol de gamb,
Come, thou shalt have reward.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And what pay have you for pandership,

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Little or nothing, it comes short of the bawd always.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A bawd, why what's a bawd, pander?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why bawd, I'll tell thee what a bawd is.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then pander I will tell thee what a pander is.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: A bawd's a thing that when the devil plays at 〈◊〉, bawd
He turns up trump, because she's a help.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But the pander playing with the devil robs thee
To make his hand the stronger, and the cards being
The devils, he makes out a little heart (And that's all
He has) into the stock.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: The devil vies it with the bawd.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The pander being drunk sees the devil.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: The devil plays on, and loses the bawd.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And takes away the knave (Which is the pander)
With his five finger.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And fearing he has not tricks enough
Gives up his dealing to the bawd, so they shuffle again.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Enough of this game.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Well, the maidenhead is
In this enchanted castle, thou must blow up,
give fire old linstock, I confess I am repulsed ith' van;
If thou failest too the King comes with a murdering piece
In the rear, o 'tis a royal service.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Well, leave it to me sir.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: She, she sallies upon thee, as 〈…〉 beus, Corothus, and all the fiends of the flesh
sp.l: Stand at thine elbow.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Bless ye fair virgin:

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: From your age with a virgin epitaph, if you
No better be than I esteem you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Twere pity
Indeed you should be a virgin to my age
Sweet beauty, you would be like a garment long laid by,
And out of fashion, which though new, would not be worth a wearing:

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Is that your companion
Parted with you?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No companion lady,
But a friend of mine, as I hope he is of yours.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You're both naught then, and neither friends of mine.
But here you have me prisoner in your power
If you have ought to speak to me out with't.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You're beloved lady, and which is more,
Yea most,
Of a King beloved.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: A good induction;
And all this I may deserve being a loyal subject.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Your loyalty may be mixed with his royalty,
If you'll be ruled, understand, Kings are not common things,
Nor are their actions common; all things are
Proper, and peculiar unto them, so ladies
Whom they love, are commonly proper ladies, who being
Proper, cannot be counted common.

sp.speaker: I●●.
sp.l: 'Tis all
My pride, I'll be accounted proper.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Only to a King.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And common to all the world besides,
That were gross.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You wrest my meaning virgin, I would not have you be

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: A virgin, is not that your meaning?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Now you come to me;
'Tis true: for what is a virgin? knew you as much
As I you'd ne'er be a virgin.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I dare swear I should not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: A virgin? why 'tis as much as to say because
You were born a child you should ever be so;
This were ridiculous. Virginity,
Why 'tis a jewel kept in a casket,
Which never opened, as good you never had it;
Shall musk be always kept in the cod, how shall
The sweetness be tasted then? Virginity is
Like a false friend to you, which indeed is better lost than kept,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Out shame of women, thou the falsest art,
Be lost for ever looking on my face,
Or lose those instruments thou lookest withal,
Immodesties in men are venial,
When women rebel against their weaker selves.
Out hag, turn thee into some other shape,
Or I shall curse myself for being one
Of thy bad sex.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay, I have done with you lady,
If flags of truce will not serve, you must look
For defiance, and here he comes that brings it with him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: All powers of goodness guard me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Speak, is she pliant?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Stubborn as an elephant's leg, no bending in her,
You know what you have to do my liege, trees that
Will not yield their fruit by gentle shaking, must
Be climbed, and have it pulled by violence.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Give leave.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I would she would give leave as soon
as I, you should not be troubled to ask a duty
From me, I would fall at your feet my liege.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why turn you from us lady?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O my liege,
I turn not from your face, but from your power,
You bring a frown, I dare not look upon.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Your thoughts instruct you ill, I do not frown, 〈◊〉
But smile upon you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I crave your pardon, and bent
My knee, your true obedient servant, my life
I'll lay an offering at your feet, what more
Would you from your humble 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nothing so much,
But for less them either, thy love fair virgin.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Keeping that name, you have it ever.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What name?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: A virgin, you have my prayers dayly to heaven
For your long sovereignties, your honour's health and victories.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: 'Tis good, and will you deny yourself, what you wish
From others? I would achieve a victory from you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Sir, I am not your foe.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Concluded well;
Approve yourself a friend, the war is love,
Wherein we two must strive make it no war,
But yield it freely.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: It is not love you seek;
But an antipathy as dissonant
As heaven and hell, the music of the spheres.
Compared with 〈◊〉, and the 〈◊〉 below.
Can lust be called love, then let men seek hell,
For there that 〈◊〉 deity doth dwell.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: We come not to dispute of good, and bad,
Do as your sex has done, taste what's forbid,
And then distinguish of the difference,
I come not now to war with eloquence,
Those treaties are all passed, if you embrace
Our proffered love, we'll pray; or call it lust,
if not, we speak a King to you, you must

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Will you be a ravisher?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Cal't as you please,
We have a burning fever, and the disease
You must lay balsum to.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Poison be it,
A serpentine, and deadly aconite,
Never survive to know what you have done,
But perish in the deed, or ere begun.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: These blasts are Zephyr's breath, a gentle galt
When it blows high.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Then let my 〈◊〉 prevail.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The sacrifice of fools, the proverbs scorn,
None pities women's ●●●res, but idiots born.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Remember what my father does for you,
He's gone to brandish 'gainst your enemies,
He's fetching you honour home; while at home
You will dishonour him.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: My purpose 'twas,
To send him forth the better to achieve
My conquest here.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Tyrannous unkingly.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Tush, I have no ears.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: He'll be revenged.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Pity, not future fears.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Help, help, some good hand help:

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There's none within thy call.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Heaven hears.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Tush, 'tis far off.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: See heaven, a wicked King, lust stains his crown,
Or strike me dead, or throw a vengeance down.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Tush heaven is deaf, and hell laughs at thy cry.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Be cursed in the act, and cursed die.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I'll stop the rest within thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not the messenger returned from the castle
With answer from Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: See my lord, they come together.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Noble Julianus, the dignity of general
You wear, be with your valour individual,
Till we have made it triple by our conquests,
Then let that threefold one, impale your brows,
And bear it to King rod 〈…〉 in triumph.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Worthy Alonzo you must help your wishes
Ere they can take effect, your approved arm
Will be a good assistant, but I pray sir,
How have you kept your castle so unbruised?
The foe not far distant, have you not ta'en
Nor given? no sallying forth, no buffetting?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: My lord, we have been yet as quiet as in league,
Which makes me guess their number is not full,
They have not yet, unless with grim aspects
So much as frighted this my tender daughter.

sp.speaker: Di●.
sp.l: Tender father, I pray let not your pity disparage me,
I have seen a sword whipped out stark naked in my time,
And never squeaked; do you think a Sarazins head,
Or a blackamoor's face can affright me, let me then
Be afraid of every chimney sweeper.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Good spirit yffaith;
Even such a soldier have I left behind,
I had much ado to keep her from the field,
Poor Jacinta, had I known such a sworn sister for her
I should almost have given her leave.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I'll tell you sir,
Were there a band of buskined Amazons
That would tuck up their skirts, and strike indeed
My girl should wear bright Menalippa's belt
she should be foremost; and I'll venture her.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Is she such a striker, my lord?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: All at head,
Nowhere else, believe me sir, we hold it base.
To strike below the waist.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: You fight high lady.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So she does at heart I think,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So, so, to her bachelor,
Antonio, Lazarelle, Medina, come Alonzo,
You and I must 〈◊〉 more seriously upon our war intendments.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: The general wrongs you to call you bachelor, Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Would he did not wrong me.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Have not you a cord●●ke
A heart fever now, 〈◊〉 do you think there is
A phoenix now, is there but one good face
In the world?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I see nothing in her face,
Prithee attempt to make her speak again.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Her tongue? nay if you like her tongue, you must needs
Like her tail, for the one utters the other● lady
What would you give now for Moors heads by the dozen?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I would buy by the score sir.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: And what a score then?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Chalk best for the score, every alewife knows that.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: You talk of chalk, and I of cheese.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: He's in the last dish, pray take him away here.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: I have not done yet, will you buy any ware of me?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What? proffered ware●●oh.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give o'er, thou wilt be foiled else.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: Why, here's a wench now, I had rather I'll with her
Wit, then with the best piece of flesh in Christendom,
I could beget young Mercuries on her, with
The very conceit: would you had had a good pair
Of eyes in your head.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They are false glasses, and will
Deceive me.
My lords to arms, the foe discovered,
Marching amain upon you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We are in readiness, our counsels broke,
Advice must be all blows, lady to your hold,
And at advantage, see what these youths will do;
To gain your love, nobly for Spain speak drum,,
And if they call, answer for us, they come.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter muly m 〈…〉 King of the Moors.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Descend thy sphere, thou burning deity,
Haste from our shame, go blushing to thy bed,
Thy sons we are, thou overlasting b●ll,
Yet never shamed these our impressive brows
Till now; we that are stamped with thine own seal,
Which the whole ocean cannot wash away:
Shall those cold ague cheeks that nature moulds
Within her winter shop, those smooth white skins,
That with a palsy hand she paints the limbs,
Make us recoil.

sp.speaker: Zac.
sp.l: Great muly 〈…〉 haste,
Either give heart to our retiring troop
By a fresh onset, or haste to safety by
Flight and baseness: b 〈…〉 slain,

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Where's our brother Mahu Mahomet?

sp.speaker: Zac.
sp.l: Rounded with danger,
Where he behaves himself nobly haldi 〈…〉 ay,
E●●ser, and five Alchaides more are gone
Up to his rescue, and if not more he dies.
Or is captived.

sp.speaker: Mull:
sp.l: We'll partake either or both with him,
They are both noble, but too basely fli●
is to preserve life, and let honour die.
Fall then my flesh, so there survive my name,
Who flies from honour, follows after shame.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Julianus, Antonio, and Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Antonio, now by the saint of Spain
You have made yourself remarkable today,
Valour, exceeding valour, was not looked for
Which you have shown today.

sp.speaker: Al●n.
sp.l: So nobly sir, that I could wish my daughter
Were in love with you, and your virtues; would you
Requite it, her dowry should be 50 thousand crowns,
More than I ever meant it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O heart, thou speak'st too late.
My lords your praises, and your noble wishes
Makes me esteem myself behind hand with fame
Here's yet more work to do.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: One muly we have ta'en,
If Mumen fly not, he's his fellow-captive.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There my new fortunes shall their honour prove,
Then fare well war, next we'll war fair with love.

div.stage: Alarum, excursions. Enter Iuli 〈…〉 and Medina, with two prisoners.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Medina, post to King Roderiqus, do thus and thus,
Tell our royal master what work we have done him:
You see and know, and it need no relation,
Here are royal prisoners.

sp.speaker: Moores.
sp.l: How will you use us?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: As in captivity we wish ourselves.

sp.speaker: Anbo
sp.l: May we not be ransomed?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: As from the King
We shall receive: as his pleasure returns us,
Mean time you shall have cause to blame
Your fortunes, not your conquerors , where's 〈◊〉
the best deserver of this day's honour.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Retired to his tent.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not wounded, is her

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: No my lord, but weary.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So we are all,
Now we have time to rest, and get new breath,
We conquer to the life, and not to death.

div.stage: Enter Antonio reading a letter, Lazarello.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: Now Antonio, where's Margaretta now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Laza.
sp.l: Who's that in your hand then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know not, look, 'tis gone.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Fie, you'll take it up again, come, come, sloop,
This is dio 〈…〉 character: a hand worth your heart,
Peruse it better, so, so, 'tis well.
Lady's fair hands must not be rejected so,
I did foresee this dangerous relapse,
You are in love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With Marg 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: With Di 〈…〉
Nor do you shame it, rather cherish it.
It is a choice 〈…〉 king your high blood;
What you have done, make 〈◊〉 as a say
Unto your best desires.

sp.speaker: Aut.
sp.l: O Lazarello!
Thou givest me poison to recure a wound
Already mortal.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Why this is speedless haste,
I know your sated pleasures would throw up
Their overcloyed receipt, you have been noble
In your brave deeds of arms; who shall 〈◊〉 it,
Your beggar's issue? they are antipathies,
How would it sound to hear poor Margaret say
Her lord hath brought home honour from the wars:
'Twould stain your worth to be so vainly boasted.
No, this lady would multiply your praises with her phrase,
lest Dionysia say that her Antonio
Won the palm of victory, then you're throned,
And music gracing the solemnity.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: One word confutes thee, ever into silence,
I am married.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: A mistake in private, who knows that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Margaretta,
And myself, besides a thousand witnesses within

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Quit you those, and who dares speak it else?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who dares not speak a truth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Dares not, who dares?
What danger is more great than to speak truth?
If poor ones durst speak plain of great men's faults,
There needed no libelling.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll choke freedom;
O what a bed of 〈◊〉 struggle within me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Tush, they are but worms, and I'll give thee seed and reasons
To destroy 'em; you're married.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A good physician;
Thou killest me quickly to haste me out of pain.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Tush, I must first draw the corruption forth,
And then apply the healing medi 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Persuade me to turn Turk, or Moor Mahometan,
For by the lustful laws of m 〈…〉
I may have three wives more.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And concubines besides; turn Moor?
Do you expect such counsel from your friend?
Wrong me not so, I'll show you a Christian way
At least a way dispensed with Christians,
Say you distaste your 〈◊〉. as well you may,
When truth shall be 〈…〉 ▪ and shame walk by,
Bearing a blushing 〈◊〉 to light them both,
Mend then the cause before it take effect,
Annihilate your 〈◊〉 that 〈◊〉 cause,
'Tis private yet, let it 〈…〉:
Allow your 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
She may be 〈◊〉 to 〈…〉
to embrace you, say she be called your whore
For some thing that may breed from what is done,
Better her shame then yours; a common thing:
Poor beauties are proud of noble bastardy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fearful counsel.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Does your Margaret love you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Beyond her life.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good, marry di 〈…〉, grief kills her, then are you a widower.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Horrible murder, 'twere less 〈◊〉
To kill at once, then by a lingring poison.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha? poison? what white devil prompted that?
Poison, brave, the very change of friendship, the trial
Of a friend's love to death, would you 〈◊〉 sure
Of a friend's constancy, a swift poison will strike it dead.
And 〈◊〉 the 〈◊〉 way and 〈◊〉 be 〈◊〉
Even in the 〈◊〉 of love, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, I dri 〈…〉 to you,
Or accept these gloves, the 〈◊〉, the touch, the sight,
Tush, any sense will take it kindly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll hear no more from thee thou studiest to make worse
A positive bad, by a vild performance .

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha?
Look yonder, there's an eye speaker 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
In very silence, where's poor Marg 〈…〉 now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O my 〈◊〉.
Look upon that face; well, you're my friend,
And by that 〈◊〉 loves ●not, had I that face
But in reversion after your decease,
I think I should give you physic fort.

sp.speaker: D●●.
sp.l: Worthy sir,
My noble father entreats some words with you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A happy messages in 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 to him,
How shall I quit your 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: D●●.
sp.l: I'll take my travel sort sir.
'Tis too little.

sp.speaker: Di●.
sp.l: I 〈◊〉 it too much sir,
for I was loath to have traveled thus far, had not
Obedience tide me to't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You're too quick.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Too quick sir, why what occasion have I given you
To wish me dead?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I cannot keep this pace with you, lady,
I'll go speak with your father.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I pray stay sir, I'll speak with you myself.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Before your father.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: No, here in private by yourself.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'll stop my ears, madam.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why, are they running away from your head sir?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: I mean I'll seal them up from hearing, lady.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: You may, no doubt they have wax o'their own.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Venture thy 〈◊〉 no farther good 〈◊〉,
She will endanger 'em, but lady now I think on
Speak, is not this your hand?

sp.speaker: D●●.
sp.l: I have three then it should seem,
For I have two of my own fingering.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is your letter?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: You know my mind then by this time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If I may be your expositor, lady, I think I do.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: And how do you expound me sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Kind and loving.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Kind and loving ▪ 'twere a good commendations
For a sow and her pigs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You ask me the reason why I enquired your age of your father.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: 'Tis true sir, for what have you to do with my age?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'd rather have to do with your youth lady.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Who, my page?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fie madam, you're too apprehensive, too dexterious,
Your wit has two edges I pr 〈…〉 st.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What a cut would that give to a 〈◊〉 crown.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My crown itches not 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Yet you may scratch it though.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, come, your wits a good one, do not 〈◊〉 it.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Unless it remove 〈◊〉 of my 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
for I must tire that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I think you love me.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: You and I may be of two opinions,
I think not so now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, your hand has betrayed you,
Do not you plainly say here, we two should be well matched?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: ●o strange, he steals half a text to uphold
His heresy; but what follows, we should be well matched
At a game of shuttlecock, the meaning is,
For a couple of light headed things we could not be over matched;
He might have conceited that that could have but said
B to a battledore: but come sir, you have said
Enough to me, will you go speak with my father?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This I'll add first, which I'll avouch unto
Your father's face, I love you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: This I'll confirm to you,
And to my father's face, but I'll not promise you,
Whether I blush or no, I do not hate you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll follow you, yet give me leave ere you go
To give a gratitude unto your lip.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: My lips do not stand in the high way to beg
A charity, as open as they appear to you.
You'll follow me sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I cannot stay long after.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Soft I'm in your debt sir, did you bestow a kiss on me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I did so far presume.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Take it again —
So now I am out of your debt, hereafter never fear
To lend freely to one that pays so willingly.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Now sir, what do you do?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am dissolving an enigma.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Let me help you, what is't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would sane know
What kind of thing a man's heart is.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Were you never
At barber surgeons hall to see 〈◊〉 dissection?
I'll report it to you, 'tis a thing framed
With divers corners, and into every corner
a man may entertain a friend, there came
The proverb, a man may love one well, and yet
Retain a friend in a corner.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tush, 'tis not
The real heart, but the unseen faculties.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Those I'll decipher unto you, for surely
The most part are but ciphers; the heart indeed.
For the most part doth keep a better guest
Than himself in him, that is the soul: now the soul
Being a tree, there are divers branches spreading out of it,
As loving affection, suffering sorrows, and the like,
Then sir, these affections, or sorrows, being but branches,
Are sometimes lopped off, or of themselves wither,
And new shoot in their rooms. As for example;
Your friend dies, there appears sorrow, but it quickly
Withers, then is that branch gone, again you love a friend,
There affection springs forth, at last you distaste,
Than that branch withers again, and another buds
In his room, shall I give you history to this moral?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, I can do't myself, o Margaretta.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: So she's in the vocative case already, if she slide.
Into the ablative, she's thrush quite out of the numbers

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am lost Lazarella.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I shall find you again
In Dionisia's arms.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Must I back slide.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.l: If you can find in your heart, you must.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My hearts
A rebel to me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Faith all your body
Will be accessary to't, I'm a friend.
Come, come, league with your thoughts, you are too nice.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How ill thou speakest of good, how good of 〈◊〉?
'Tis now concluded in me, I will on,
I must, although I meet destruction.
Down hill we run, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 a slow 〈◊〉
Easy descents to hell, 〈…〉.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Quiet your tongue, or I'll take away your liberty,
Know you're under me, and my command.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Quiet my tongue? Art officer of hell!
Thou jailor to the devil, fleshly fiend,
I'll waken heaven and earth with my exclaims,
Astonish hell for fear, the fire be doubled
In the due vengeance of my heinous wrong,
My heavy heinous wrong.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Forbear I say: you are a crack virgin,
And I'll bestow the widow alms on you
In charity, if you not hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Worst of humanity, hold thou thy tongue,
Shame thou to speak, my shame enforceth me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Come, come, my li●le (What shall I call thee)
For it is now doubtful what thou art; being neither
Maid, wife, nor (Saving your reverence) widow.
Ha? Dost spit at me? I'll have you spitted for this trick,
And I will turn you as you see, and moreover
I will haste you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O that I could spit out the spider's bladder,
Or the roads entrails into thee, to take part
And mix with the diseases that thou hearst,
And altogether choke thee, or that my tongue
Were pointed with a 〈…〉 y pyramis
To strike thee through, thou bundle of diseases,
This store-house of some shaggy meteor,
Some blazing fire shone o'er thy 〈◊〉 birth,
And laid up all her sad effects in that,
Gouts, aches, dropsies, and a hundred more,
For were not 〈◊〉 to 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
Thy own soul 〈◊〉 would strangle thee.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Thou art a looser, and I do consider it,
Thou hast lost a maidenhead, a shrewd crack:
A flaw that will hardly be soldered again;
Some there be that can pass away these counterfeits.
For currant, as brass money may be taken
For silver, yet it can never be the same,
Nor restored to his first purity, this I consider.
And bear, (But presume not too much to trouble
The pool of my patience, it may rise soul) it may.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O that thine eyes were worth the plucking out,
Or thy base heart, the labour I should take
In rending up thy bosom, I should but open
A vault to poison me (Detested wretch)
The hangman's man, basest degree of baseness,
Thou livest upon the lees and dregs of lust,
Thy soul is a hired hackney towards hell.
O Julianus, my much honoured father,
How is thy simple faith deluded now!
Thou hadst not so much thought of ill in thee,
To breed a bad opinion of a villain,
Tyrant, and ravisher; whilst thou art winning
Renown and honour from Spain's enemies,
Spain has dishonoured and imprisoned me:
Thou understandest not this, unless the winds
Upon their fleeting convey hear it thee,
Some gentle vision tell thee in thy sleeps,
And heaven instruct thee with a waking faith,
True to believe thy slumbers; boil out my blood,
And at the briny limbeck of mine eyes
Distil my faculties; alone I'll tell
My sorrows unto heaven, my curse to hell.
And there 〈◊〉 mix that wretch, from thence they rise,
O whilst I look on him, I loathe mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But that I have some kinder purpose, I would not
Be thus baited: I am given to the 〈◊〉 as well
As the King my master, I have some hope to taste
This dish after him; but 'tis yet too hot for me,
It will cool, and then I will draw my 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 have
a flash at it: this woman's two edged tongue,
And this burden of flesh that I bear about me,
Hath made me so heavy, I must take a ●●p.
Cob, boy, Cob, page.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: There is some thing gone
Into my ears, that troubles my brain, blow in
Some music to fetch it out again.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: The best I can, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And hark you, having done, ascend the turret
And see if you can discover his majesty
Coming to the castle: this house he appointed
For his recreation, if you do, descend,
And give me 〈…〉 warning.

sp.speaker: C●●.
sp.l: I will.
sp.stage: A song wit him. 〈◊〉 falls asleep.
sp.l: So I have lulled my lord asleep,
I see he takes my music heavily,
Therefore I'll sing no more: now to my turret
To see if the King come, now he may take him napping.

sp.speaker: Jao.
sp.l: There is no resting place within a prison
To make my sorrows less by recounting.
I throw they forth, but empty none 〈◊〉 all;
Ha, asleep? Ay, security can sleep,
Griefs a true watchman: how the d 〈…〉
Th' 〈…〉 ●ell within high 〈…〉, and what a 〈◊〉 noise
I could with h●● office 〈…〉
But I have better though 〈…〉 may give me
My release 〈…〉
of better release, no, I will not delay it,
I will keep back my sins from multitudes,
And I may fly for safety to my father.
There's divers ways, heaven instruct the privat'st.
And best for my escape: fare ill, not well,
Thou and thy lustful master: from all but one,
This key now frees me, o! that I bear about,
Which none but mercy's key can deliver out.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: My lord, I spy the King coming pri 〈…〉 ely
By himself, my lord, one were as good attempt
To wake a watchman at three o'clock in the morning,
My lord, lend me your keys if you'll not 〈◊〉 yourself:
Methinks he should wake himself with 〈◊〉, but 〈◊〉 may be
The more noise makes him sleep the sounder; the best is,
I take it, the King has a private key to let in himself;
If he have, he will do his own work himself, and my lord
For this time shall be an innocent pander,
In this act of sleep a harmless husband may be so
To his own wife, 'tis as I guest, he is come
In of himself.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Where's your master?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: In his private meditations, my liege.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: He was ever heavy, where's 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Safe enough,
My liege, she 〈◊〉 my lord into these 〈◊〉
With the very music of her tongue, but they 〈◊〉 all discord.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Command here 〈◊〉, her father 〈…〉,
He has a noble fortune to 〈…〉 king 〈◊〉
Conquest and royal 〈◊〉, I 〈◊〉 not well
Requite him: therefore I 〈…〉
what I return, how the villain snores!
Sleep on sir, your sin will be the less, in being
My bawd. Now where is she?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Alas my lord,
I have been —.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Been imp, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Seeking about all the corners in the castle
For Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why, is she to seek slave?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: I can neither hear nor see her anywhere .

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Rogue, thou neither seest, nor hear'st more if I see not her:

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: I'll go seek better, my liege, I doubt some legerdemain,
But if I find not her within, I know the way out.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You dormouse, baby of fifty, bundle of security,
Awake rogue, pocks of your heavy flesh, hast thou no soul?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Minion, I'll clog your heels with irons for this,
Will you not let me rest by you?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Mischief open your eyelid 〈…〉 block, image.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I will tell the King, and he shall tickle you for this.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sir death, I'll tickle you for this, loggerhead, where's 〈…〉?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: O my liege, is it your maiesty, I beseech you pardon me:
These after dinner-naps are the repasts to my body.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Diseases devour your body, where's 〈…〉?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Safe, safe, my liege, my keys, where he my keys,
Saw you my keys, my 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Confirmed, she has the keys, and is fled the castle,
Dog, hellhound, thou shalt be my 〈◊〉, sl 〈…〉
I'll drag this 〈…〉 ull 〈◊〉 into his 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay but my 〈…〉.
And the 〈◊〉 I●old 〈…〉 by 〈◊〉
when I went to sleep, and my first dream told me
They were there still. My boy, my Cob, saw you my Cob, my liege?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Dogs worry you both; search slave in every angle,
Send pursuit after her, if thou returnest her not,
Thou shalt curse thy being.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: If she be not above steeples,
Nor beneath hell, I'll find her, for so high
And low I can reach and dive, as heavy as I am.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: If she escape us, and once reach her father,
Now in his height of honour, we know not how
He may receive his wrongs, nor the event;
We will command him distant from the court,
And his prisoners sent to us; and this shall haste
Before her possible speed, if she scape:
We'll threaten his heads loss, if he deny they,
Those that do wrong, had need keep safety by 'em.

div.stage: Enter Marg 〈…〉 and Fydella the Moor.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O that some striking air had blasted me
Before this poison entered at mine cares;
Married?

sp.speaker: Fy.
sp.l: Madam, sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam! prithee mock me not, nor guard my folly
With such a linsey wolsey ornament.
Madam, is the mad dame, and thence mad woman:
Define it so and I will borrow still
That little of my store. A coat of tissue
If a fool wears it, is but a fool's coat.
Such are my trappings; o for time that's gone,
Equality, o sweet equality,
Born under Libra, thou hast both right hands,
Without advantage, or priority.
Base ones made big by beauty are but slaves,
Their lords never truly bed but in their graves.
Hai a dangerous conceit, call my brother, Fidella.

sp.speaker: Fy.
sp.l: Then let me council you, know he's open,
plain, and rustical, and altered from his first condition,
Whatever your purpose is, let it not appear to him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Prithee be gone, and call him.
Am I despised so soon? wedlock unjust,
Unequal nuptials are not love, but lust:
Come back passed time, o 'tis a fruitless call,
I may repent, but find no help at all.
Now I forestall thee heaven ere I begin,
Forgive me, I must act some a heinous sin,
I must now be changed.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ia. Lady sister, did your madamship
Send for my worship?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I did send for you brother.

sp.speaker: Iai
sp.l: You may entreat me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I hope so, I have a letter
To my lord (Brother) containing so much love
And secrecy; as I would trust none willingly
But yourself for the delivery.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: A letter sister!
I would not have you to take me for a carrier,
Or a porter to carry words, or letters more
Than it pleases me; yet in the way of a nuntius,
Partly ambassador, or so, I will
Travel for your sake.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look you, this is all, brother.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Is this all sister?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Unless you'll add another:
Commends by word of mouth ▪

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: By word of mouth?
'Twas not well spoken sister.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why brother?

sp.speaker: Jailor
sp.l: Why what words are there, but words of the mouth?
Except it be words of the tail, which would sound but il●
In my lord brother's cares: for words behind
A man's back are but wind, you know that.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But be most careful in the delivery, I entreat you brother;
You know our wedding is only known to us,
A thing concealed from wide mouthed rumour, then should you
Find him in company with nobles of his own rank.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Tush, I can smell the rankest of them all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Say amongst ladies you should find him sporting
Dancing, kissing, or any such like wantonness,
Take heed your rude approach does not move him to any distaste.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: O my noun sister, my nose is a little more a kin to you
Now then ever it was; you would have me be an informer
Of unlawful games, as tick-tack, whipper ginny, in and in.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No trust me brother, only to instruct you I speak;
For the least disparagement should chance to him
His pleasure forbidding it, would be a death to me,

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Well sister, here's my hand, and my heart is somewhere
Here about me too, but I'd be loath to bring him
Forth to witness, but I will be very careful.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You undo me else brother.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Pha, d'ye think me for
A fool or your brother (Sister)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do not think
But at your return I shall be very thankful.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: As for that, it is sufficient your ladyship is my sister; o ye little amiable rogue you, a good face is a good dowry, I see sometimes; when we two tumbled both in a belly together, little did our mother think which should have been the madam; I might have been cut the tother way i'faith, if it had pleased the sisters three, if the midwife had but known my mind when I was born, I had been two stone lighter; but much good do thee with thy good fortunes; farewell honourable flesh and blood, I will deliver to my noble brother, pretty trim lady, I think we are eyed alike; fare thee well, I cannot choose but see thee as long as I look upon thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Effect thy own content, paper and ink,
And than thou bringst the work into my hands.
Fudella.

sp.speaker: Fud.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou lovest me Fudella.

sp.speaker: Fud.
sp.l: Do you make a question on't lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, I rather
Speak it as acknowledgement, suppose I went
In the right noble way, to meet my foe
I'th field, wouldst be my second.

sp.speaker: Fud.
sp.l: To my second life, madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do intend no such virago's part,
But in shape, a danger to thee far more worse,
But when 'tis done, the spacious world shall have to understand,
Spite of the low condition of my birth,
High spirits may be lodged in humble earth.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Sad still!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am as I was ever lady,
Full of retired thoughts.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: You draw these backward
Should be coming on, and meet in nuptial pleasures.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All strive to be their own physicians (Lady)
We know what's best and fittest to be done,
But who can follow it?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Till the disease be known
In vain it were to study remedy,
Pray what's your cause of sadness?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have none, lady.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why are you not merry then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You must find fault with my complexion for't,
Nature, perhaps, has not compounded me
Of equal portions; yet you discover
Diseases outward, I not feel within,
Methinks I'm merry.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: No, I have heard you sigh so violent,
they have woken my slumbers with you in bed,
One gust following another, as you would breathe
Out all your air together, there most be cause.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know not how to win your good belief, lady,
But if you'll trust me; Lazarello come hither.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: A murrain oh the carrier brought me hither, I shall sit the worse this two days, but I think I have requited his sides for't; now to my letter, pat yffaith, here's my noble brother; hum, I have a pestilent lady to my sister, she told me I should find him amongst ladies; if she had said lady she had guessed singular well yffaith, I will carry it as well as I can for my honourable brother's credit.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Fie, that's a lame excuse, you won not honour
Equal with your will, myself from the castle saw you,
Most nobly do, I saw you unhorse three brave opposers,
You killed and captived many enemies.

sp.speaker: Laz:
sp.l: Nay now sweet lady
You make too strict an inquisition,
Men emulate in honour for the best.
Who would be second that can foremost 〈◊〉
For this a man may wrangle with 〈◊〉 fate,
And grieve and envy at another's fortunes.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: See you you fellow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Waft him hence good Lazarello, I am undone else,
Look here Dionysia, here's a jewel,
I never showed thee yet.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: 'Tis a very pretty one,
Shall I have it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With all my heart sweet.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: He gives me aim, I am three bows too short,
I'll come up nearer next time.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: When does the army
March hence, Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Some three days hence.
I must prepare to go:

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I'll go with you Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By no means sweet, I'll send for thee
With more harmonious music.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Indeed I must.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, come, indeed you shall not.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: He wonot off sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A mischief carry him.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: No! shall I have no notice taken of me!
I'll begin in another tone with you. Hum, hum, hum,
There was a nobleman of Spain, lady, lady,
That went abroad, and came not again
To his poor lady.
O cruel age, when one proud brother, lady, lady,
Shall scorn to look upon another,
Of his poor lady.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How now, what fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: No man's fellow here, lady, yet a good fellow too
In place where.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Who! this fellow, lady! he that knows not him,
Knows not a man of mirth, this doctor I tell you
Gives as good cure for the melancholy.
As the best empiric in Spain, whate'er he be.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I would he would practise on Antonio then.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Troth madam 'tis a good plot, please you to walk
I'll man you to the castle, leave them together,
'Tis an equal match, if he make him not merry,
He'll most terribly trouble his melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He'll make me more sad I fear.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I had rather stay and partake some mirth.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I am no woman's fool (Sweet lady) 'tis two trades in Seville; as your man's tailor, and your woman's tailor: so your lords fool, and your lady's fool, I am for the tongue, not for the bauble.

sp.speaker: Di●.
sp.l: Well Antonio, I'll leave you, and sirrah make him merry,
And I'll reward thee:

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: If I cannot make him merry, I know who can.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Who I prithee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Twill out.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Why my — you can lady.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Now you jest too broad sirrah.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: That's woman's jesting, madam.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I was afraid he would have named his sister.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I will make bold to be covered, brother thou knowest

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O brother.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Look thee there's black and white for thee from the little honourable rascal my sister, and a thousand commendations too without book, which I was bid to tell thee by rote, if thou canst read and hear all at once.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes I can.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: There's honourable bones a breeding, my sister is the peevishest piece of lady's flesh grown of late, we have good sport at it to see her vex and fret, she boxes me as familiarly as if I were her cobbler, for talking to her, an unnatural varlet, to strike her own flesh and blood, but I bear with her for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I thank you fort, brother.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Nay, she cuts her lace, and eats raw fruit too, what salad do you think she longed for tother day?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know not:

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: For a what do call 'em? those long upright things that grow a yard above the ground; o cuckoo pintle roots, but I got her her belly full at last.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So 'twas well.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: But the best lest was, she bit her shoemaker by the ear as he was drawing on her shoes; and another time her tailor for girding her too straight, he had a long nose, but she did so pinch his bill; what, hast thou good news brother?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Very good brother, all I read are well.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Yes faith brother, we are in health, and drink to thine sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Brother, I would have your swift return.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: 'Twas my sister's charge, she thinks of long things, poor heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I cannot give you the entertainment I would brother, but I pray you let this provide for you.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: This is hostess, tapster, chamberlain, and all, brother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In the morning early my letter shall be ready for you.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I will lie in my boot all night, but I'll be ready as soon as your letter: bonos nocios, mi frater.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stay brother, one thing I must ask you,
And pray you tell me, what's your thought of me,
Finding me in a lady's company?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: O brother, I would not have you think you have a fool to your kindred, what! I understand these toys, there are fowl, and there are fish, there are wagtails, and there are mermaids.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Of what sort do you think she is?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: O brother, definitions and distinctions! fie on they, come, I know flesh and blood will be sporting. And I were a married man myself, I would not always be at home, I would hawk, and hunt, and ride, there are divers members in one body, there are flesh days, and there are fish days, ●man must not always eat one sort of meat.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I see you are a wag brother.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Always let a married man get his own children at home if he can, if he have a bit abroad for procreation or so —.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well good night brother, I pray hold a good opinion of me.

sp.speaker: Iaq:
sp.p: O sir, I can wink with one eye like a gunner, shall I make my sister sick of the yellow jaundice? no, thought is free, whatsoever I speak, I'll say nothing; vale, valete, valete, valetote. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I can dissemble mirth no longer.
O my afflicted soul, wert thou capable
Of separation, thou wouldst now be rent
Into a thousand pieces: 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Now sir, you are full of news I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Heavy and froward news: where's Dionysia?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: At distance enough in the castle; you may speak.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am discovered, Margaretta knows of this
Her wrong, and my disloyalty.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: It was no mystery,
And must be found, but how does she bear it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Better then her birth,
As well as my addition to her, nobly,
And if her hand does not belie her heart,
She's glad that I have found an equal liking.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: She has done as becomes her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yet with this request,
That I would not forsake her utterly,
But some times see her, 'tis articled too,
That twice a week she have my fellowship
By night, and private stealths, the which obtained,
She lose the name of wife, and never shame
To be called my concubine.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Ay, this is well,
Fine light pageant work, but now sure building,
This gilds a while, but will at length wash off again;
This roof must be raised upon a sounder ground-fill;
Give me your free bosom, you have one heart, and two ways,
Which may have the better part freely.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My conscience
And my affection war about this quarrel,
My conscience saith the first, but my affection,
The second.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: So then, you should
Love Margaretta, but do love Dionysia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My heart's triangled, two points Dionisia's,
And that downwards Margaret's, and that's the smallest.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: I thank you for this free delivery:
you seal your friendship to me, now let me build,
I have't, I'll rid your griefs at once; will you
But give consent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To any fair condition.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: No worse than Margaret's request to you,
Or very little, return your letter, that
You will satisfy all her desire, appoint
Your first night's approach, and privately.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Night cannot hide it ever.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: But hear me,
You shall not go, I will supply your place,
Not to blemish, but to preserve your honour:
Command your entertainment, so secret be,
As that no lights may lead you to your chamber,
Let me alone to counterfeit for once,
And once shall serve for all, if it but take,
And that she bed with me, not for the act,
For there your honour must be weighed, but company,
Shall serve the turn, then rise I and proclaim
Both our luxurious sin 〈…〉; how 〈◊〉 she then
Claim any part in you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange extreame●

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Ulcers must have co 〈…〉 sives to eat, not skinned,
Extremes must have extremes to cope withal.
It will not yield else.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I like it, and allow it;
'Tis more than water that must fight with wild fire.
This passage shall be inst 〈…〉 lie prepared
With some of my wearings, brought as near myself
As art can make, this ring to strengthen it,
I could subtract a third from my estate
To heal her injury, and quite blot out
That taints mine honour, being voiced,
It must be cured; pardon heaven and Margaret,
There is an innate falling from what's good,
Which nothing can repair in's but our blood.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That I should ten leagues be in scorn removed
From court unto my country house! for what?
'Tis very strange; know you the cause?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Not I, my lord.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I cry you mercy sir, and my King mercy,
And I beshrew my thoughts for be 〈…〉 g troubled.
I know the canst myself, his gr●ce is wise,
For seeing me on a 〈◊〉 of 〈◊〉,
So eye-able to the world, the 〈◊〉 slaves,
The multitude in their loud be 〈…〉 g voices,
Might add so much to me sir, as might dim
His own proper 〈◊〉, for such 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 see
The present 〈◊〉, 〈…〉, or 〈◊〉,
He gives me safety 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
Himself much worth and honour, for sir, what honour
Can subjects have, but is 〈…〉
Due 〈◊〉 their Crowne●, 〈…〉,

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Your prisoners must be sent 〈◊〉 too my lord.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ha? my prisoners? 〈◊〉 go●● somewhat further,
Sir, I beef 〈…〉 yo● this day 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
Yourself into our 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 nobly 〈◊〉,
The 〈…〉 go 〈◊〉 the 〈◊〉 ●oo
This very night 〈◊〉 answer and confirm
What he commands.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Tomorrow I must return.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You shall, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 I pray be merry with us:
Commanded 〈◊〉 ●he co 〈…〉 my prisoners sent for!
'Tis strange; o my forgetful m 〈…〉 ry!
I did not ask how my 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉:
But she forgets too, minds not me her father,
We'll mix they both together, but my prisoners!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir, here's a woman (Forced by some tide of sorrow)
With tears entreats your pity, and to see you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If any soldier has done violence to her,
Beyond our military discipline,
Death shall divide him from us, fetch her in.
I have myself a daugh 〈…〉, 〈◊〉 on whose face
But thinking, I must need be pitiful:
And when I ha' told my conquest to my King,
My poor girl then shall know, how for her sake
I did one pious act; is this the creature!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes, my lord, and a sad one.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Leave us: a sad one!
The downcast loo 〈…〉, calls up compassion in me,
A corse going to the gr●●e looks not more deadly,
Why kneelst thou! art thou wronged by any soldier!
Rise, for this honour is not due to me.
Hast not a tongue to read thy sorrows out!
This book I understand not.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.l: O my dear father!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thy father? who has wronged him?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: A great commander.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Under me!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Above you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Above me? whose above a general?
None but the general of all Spain's armies,
And that's the King, King Roderick; he's all goodness.
He cannot wrong thy father.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.l: What was Tarquin?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A King, and yet a 〈…〉 isher.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.l: Such a sin
Was in those days a monster, 〈◊〉 〈…〉 'tis common.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Prithee be plain.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.l: Have not you sir, a daughter?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If I have not, I am the wretchedst man
That this day lives: for all the wealth I have
Lives in that child.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.l: O for your daughters sake then hear my woes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Rise then, and speak 'em.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, let me kneel still,
Such a resemblance of a daughter's duty,
Will make you mindful of a father's love:
For such my injuries must exact from you,
A you would for your own.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And so they do,
For whilst I see thee kneeling, I think of my Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Say your Jacinta then (Chaste as the rose)
Coming on sweetly in the springing bud,
And never felt heat, to spread the summer sweet:
But to increase and multiply it more,
Did to itself keep in its own perfume:
Say that some rapine hand had plucked the bloom,
