Jacinta like that flower, and ravished her,
Defiling her white lawn of chastity,
With ugly blacks of lust; what would you do?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O 'tis too hard a question to resolve,
Without a solemn council held within
Of man's best understanding faculties:
There must be love, and fatherhood, and grief,
And rage, and many passions, and they must all
Beget a thing called vengeance; but they must sit upon't.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Say this were done by him that carried
The fairest seeming face of friendship to yourself.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We should fall out.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Would you in such a case respect degrees?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I know not that.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Say he were noble.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Impossible: th'acts ignoble, the bee can breed
No poison, though it suck the juice of hemlock.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Say a King should do '〈…〉 were th' 〈…〉 less done
by the greater power, does majesty extenuate a crime:

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Augment it rather.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Say then that Roderick, your King and master,
To quit the honours you are bringing home,
Had ravished your Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Who has sent
A fury in this foul-fair shape to vex me?
I ha' seen that face methinks , yet know it not:
How darest thou speak this treason, 'gainst my King?
Dared any man ith' world, bring me this lie,
By this, had been in hell; Roderick a Tarquin?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.l: Yes, and thy daughter (Had she done her part)
Should be the second Lucrece: view me well,
I am Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: The King my ravisher.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The King thy ravisher! o unkingly sound:
He dares not sure, yet in thy sullied eyes
I read a tragic story.
O noble friends,
Our wars are ended, are they not?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: They are sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But Spain has now begun a civil war.
And to confound me only: see you my daughter?
She sounds the trumpet, which draws forth my sword
To be revenged.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: On whom? speak loud your wrongs,
Digest your choler into temperance:
Give your considerate thoughts the upper hand,
In your hot passions, 'twill assuage the swelling
Of your big heart; if you have injuries done you,
Revenge them, and we second you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Father, dear father.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Daughter, dear daughter.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Why do you kneel to me sir?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: To ask thee pardon that I did beget thee,
I brought thee to a shame stains all the way
Twixt earth and Acheron: not all the clouds
(The skies large canopy) could they drown the s 〈…〉
With a perpetual inundation,
Can wash it ever out, leave me I pray.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: His fighting passions will be o'er anon,
And all will be at peace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Best in my judgement,
We wake him with the fight of his won honours:
Call up the army, and let them present
His prisoners to him, such a sight as that
Will brook no sorrow near it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Twas a good doctor that prescribed that physic
I'll be your patient sir, show me my soldiers,
And my new honours won, I will truly weigh them,
With my full griefs, they may perhaps o'ercome.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Why now there's hope of his recovery.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Jacinta welcome, thou art my child still,
No forced stain of lust can alienate
Our consanguinity.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Dear father,
Recollect your noble spirits, conquer grief,
The manly way: you have brave foes subdued,
Then let no female passions thus o'erwhelm you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mistake me not, my child, I am not mad,
Nor must be idle; for it were more fit,
(If I could purchase more) I had more wit,
To help in these designs, I am grown old:
Yet I have found more strength within this arm,
Then without proof I durst ha' boasted on.
Roderick thou King of monsters couldst thou do this?
And for thy lust confine me from the court,
There's reason in thy shame, thou shouldst not see me.
Ha! they come Jacinta, they come, hark, hark,
Now thou shalt see what cause I have given my King:
sp.stage: Enter Anton is with the african 〈…〉 King, 〈◊〉 other m 〈…〉 prisoners.
sp.l: Stand, pray stand all, deliver me my prisoners:
So 〈◊〉 well, wondrous well, I have no friends
But these my enemies, yet welcome brave Moors,
With you I'll parley; first I defy you all.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am a vowed for to your King, to Roderique.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How Julia 〈…〉!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay we fear you not, here's our whole army;
Yet we are strong enough from fear or flight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Make us understand a reason Julianus,
If for disloyalty reason may be given
Of this your language.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 you 〈…〉 y judges whom I make my foes?
Was my power placed above my mercy, or mercy
Above my power? went they not hand in hand?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ever most nobly.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Ever, ever.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why then should Roderique do this base deed?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You do distract us sir, beseech you name it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Behold this child of mine, this only mine,
I had a daughter, be she is ravished now.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ravished?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, by Roderique, by 〈◊〉, tire 〈…〉, Roderique:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oh most abhorred deed?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Join with me noble Spaniards in revenge.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We will.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Have I your hearts?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Our lives sh 〈…〉 ●eale it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Then princely 〈◊〉, here I free thee,
And all thy valiant Moors: wilt thou call back
Thy scattered forces, and incorporate
Their strengths with mine, and with me march through Spain,
Sharpening thy sword with vengeance for my wrong●?

sp.speaker: Moors.
sp.l: Most willingly, to bind me father to thee,
Plight me thy ravished daughter to my wife,
And thou shalt see my indignation fly
On wings of thunder.

sp.speaker: Jaci 〈…〉.
sp.l: O my second hell,
a Christian's arms embrace an infidel!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll not compel her heart, wo●e, win, and wed her:
Forced has she been too much, — my honoured friends,
What we all thought to ha' born home in triumph,
Must now be seen there in a funeral,
Wracked honour being chief mourner; here's the hearse
Which we'll all follow; — Roderique we come,
To give thy lust a scourge, thy life a doom.

div.stage: A bed discovered, on it Lazarello, as a 〈…〉: enter Margaretta and Fydella with a halter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sleeps he Fydella?

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: Slumb'ringly madam; he's not yet in his dead sleep.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis now his dying, anon comes his dead sleep.
For never shall he wake, until the world
Hath phoenixlike been hid in his own ashes,
Fydella, take my strength into thine arms,
And play the cruel executioner,
As I will first instruct thee.

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: I am so far
From shrinking, madam, that I'll gladly be
The prologue to Antony's 〈…〉 s tragedy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: An't 〈…〉 s tragedy! that very name
Should strike even sparks of pity from the flint:
Antonio! husband a 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: Remember there's another owes that name.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ay, that's that's the poison kills me; shall a strumpet
(For she's no better) rob me of a treasure
So dear to me as he was; yet her I pardon:
The master-thief lies here, and he must die fort:
All mercy hence I banish. Justice look down
To see a woman's vengeance; thus I begin,
And follow thus and thus, now I am in,
Nothing shall pull me back.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: O, o.

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: He has passage yet for breath.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here's remedy for that, pull Fydella.

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: He would speak it seems.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never; his tongue betrayed me once, I will
No more listen my temptations; hear he shall
A while, and that but deafly: Antonio,
I was your wife, lordly Antonio,
And in that balance equalled with yourself,
I was your handmaid, and you might have trod
On my humility, I had kissed your feet,
But with disdain thou trampledst on my throat,
As I do now on thine, and will deface
What nature built for honour, not deceit:
Our wedding was in private, so our divorce,
Yet this shall have as free and open blazon
As a truth-speaking goodness; oh my Fydella,
Thou little instrument of my revenge,
I would not have thee (For thy duty) lost,
There's gold; hie thee to safety, fare thee well,
I must ne'er see thee more, this place will be —

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: Not too hot for me madam; my complexion
Is natural to it: good fortunes follow you;
If I might counsel you, I would conceal it:
If you can fly, do not betray yourself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fie, prithee away, thou wilt mar all the glory,
Conceal the deed? even to the bent brow
Of the stern judge, I'll speak, and call for justice,
Proud of my glorious vengeance, I will smile
Upon my dreadful executioner:
'Twas that was first enacted in my breast,
She should not dare to kill, that dares not die,
'Tis needy mischief, and he's basely bent
That dares do ill, yet fear the punishment.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Some music.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Music sir! 'tis all untuned,
Remember your proud enemy's approach,
And your unreadiness to entertain 'em.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: If all be set upon a careless hazard,
What shall care do there?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Rouse you like a lion,
And fright this herd of foxes, wolves, and bears,
From daring to come near you: a King's eye.
Has magical charms in't to bind treason down,
They fight like thieves for spoil, you for your own;

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O Piamentelli, there's within my bosom,
An army of furies mustered, worse than those
Which follow Julianus: conscience beats
The drum of horror up.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: For what! A maidenhead!
Pray be yourself, and justify the act,
Stand on your guard, and royalize the fact
By your own dispensation.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Go call our friends together, if we have none,
Hire them with double pay, ourself will search
And break those dangerous doors which have so long
Kept Spain in childish ignorance.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: O good my lord,
Forbear, there's fatal prophecies forbid you.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There's fatal fooleries; tell me of prophecies!
Shall fear affright me? no; upon my life
'Tis hidden treasure kept for needful hours,
And now 'tis come; 'tis gold must purchase soldiers;
shall I not seek it then? alone I'll break
Open those forbidden doors, go muster men.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: This I dread more than all our enemies,
If good proceed from this, no magic art
Shall fright me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Or good, or bad, I'll throw the dice myself,
And take the chance that falls; thou art the first,
Hell wakens, yet I'll on, twenty at least
I must pass through before I break the spell,
If this door thither lead, I'll enter hell.

div.stage: Thunder and lightning. Enter Roderique again at another door.

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: So now I me entered to the fatal chamber,
Show now thy full effects, ha? what sight's this?

div.stage: Enter Julianus, Moor, Jaciuta, Antonio, Alonzo, one presenting Roderique.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: 'Tis holiday in hell, the fiends are loose,
I have enfranchised you, thank me devils;
Was this the fatal incantation
That here was locked so many fearful ages,
And was't decreed for me to dislocate?
Fire consume you geomantic devils,
Where borrowed you those bodies, you damned thieves?
In your own shapes you are not visible,
Or are you yet but fancies imaginary?
What's he that me presents? I have not sent
My carcase forth, I am not sleeping now,
And my soul strayed forth, I am my real self,
Must I be captived by a traitor so?
Devil thou playest me false; undiademed?
And such a sooty fiend inherit me?
Jacinta, too, that she-curse, must she have part?
Kneeling to them, here's a solemnity
In the devil's name; go reign in sulphur, or in
Some frozen labyrinth; this kingdom's mine:
Thou there that me personatest, draw forth thy sword,
And brandished against hell, I'll show thee how?
What magic binds me? what furies hold mine arm.
Piamentelli, Avilla, none succour me?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: What ails you sir?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: My foes are come upon me.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Coming they are, but yet a league distant, sir,

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Zounds they are come, and have been here with me.
Traitorous Julianus, and his ravished daughter,
An army of Moors, of Turks and infidels.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Your fancies trouble you, they are but coming,
Too near in that, make up to your soldiers,
Full twenty thousand now will follow you and more.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The moor's a coming, and the devil too that must
Succeed me in my last monarchy, take arms and fight,
The fiends shall know they have not played me right.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p:
O for a private place to be hanged in; when all hope's gone, welcome despair; which way soever the day goes, I'm sure this is my way; if the King overcome, I shall be hanged for Jacinta's escape, if she rise, I fall in recompense of her wrongs. All my grief is, I want an heir to have my purse and clothes, one that would take the pains for me, an honest hangman were now as good
a companion as I would desire to meet with; I have lived a lord, and I would be loath to die an executioner.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Murder is come to light; o sister how hast thou overthrown our honourable house before it was well covered; o ambitious sister, half a share in a lord would not content thee, thou would have all or none, now thou hast none, for thou hast killed thy lord and husband.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I was a lord, although a bawdy lord.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I was a lord's brother, although a bawdy lords brother.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: O lechery, how hast thou puffed me up and undone me.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: O lechery, thou hast battened me a while, and then spoilt me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ha? what art thou?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Partly honourable, partly miserable.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Give me thy halter then.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Art thou a hangman then?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Ay, and a mad one, but now I droop, and am ready to drop into the budget.

sp.speaker: Lo,
sp.p: Look here's work for thee, here's clothes, and here's money, wout thou take the pains to hang me?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I have lived a lord's brother, and would be loath to die a hangman.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Do not desire to die, live till thou diest of thine own accord.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: 'Tis my desire, but I want a cord of mine own, prithee lend me thine.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Let me persuade thee to be charitable to thyself, spare thyself, and hang me, I have been a pander, knowest thou what a pander is?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: In brief a knave; more at large thus;
He's a thing that is poor,
He waits upon a whore,
when she's sick, he's sore,
In the streets he goes before,
At the chamber waits at door,
All his life 'a runs o'th score,
This I know, and know no more.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: All this I'll add to it,
He wears long lock,
And villainous socks,
Many nights in the stocks,
Endures some knocks,
And a many of mocks,
Eats reversions of cocks,
Yet lies in the flocks,
Thrives by the smocks,
And dies with the pox.
All this I have been, and now desire to be hanged for't.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: What hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: A hundred marks, besides leases, and lands which I have wickedly gotten, all which I will bestow on thee, if thou wilt take the pains to hang me.

sp.speaker: Iaq:
sp.p: Hum? my brother is dead, and there is no way to raise our house again but by ready money or credit; the hangman many times mounts above his betters; well I will hang, but my conscience bears me witness, 'tis not for any good will I bear unto thee, nor for any wrong that I know thou hast committed; but innocently for thy lands, thy leases, thy clothes, and thy money. And so come a long with to me the next tree, where thou shalt hang till thou art dead, and stink above ground.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: With all my heart, my guts, my lights, my liver, and my lungs.

div.stage: Alarum, excursions, enter Rodorique and Piamentelli.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Fly, fly my lord.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: With what wings?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: With wings of speed.
Your foes, sir, conquer, and your soldiers bleed,
The barbarous Moor is titled by your name,
The Spanish King; therefore your safest speed
Will be to Biscany, there you may find
New friends, new safety, and new kingly minds.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There is no friendship where there is no power,
I must crave now, o poverty most poor,
To beg of them received mine alms, before.
I have defended them:

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: They'll you relieve.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I'll make the proof: what do you call the man
Whose prowess in that rightful victory
Against the Moors did so much honour win?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: He was, and is, and may be, but not long?
This poisoned julep 〈…〉 has battered him.
Thou art my subject still Piamentelli.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Whilst I am Piamentelli.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Wert thou gone,
I then might boast, I were a King alone,
For but thyself I do not know one subject,
Than subjects all, since you●● not let me die,
I'll seek a weary life in Biscany.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Thou mutable piece of nature, dost thou fly me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: That's frightful to me.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: I shall be more frightful,
If thou repel a proffered arm of love,
There will rebound a hate blacker in art
Then in similitude; forget me not,
Have not I chased thy wronger from his ground,
And my triumphant self thy conqueror?
I am thy King.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I'll fear thee then?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Not love me!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: The word is poisoned in thy very tongue,
Love thee? as I would love my ravisher.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Thy father shall repent.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: He must, and will,
That ere he freed a captive infidel.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Look for a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yes, some barbarous one,
'Tis natural to thee, base African,
Thine in side a blacker than thy sooty skin.
O Julianus, what hast thou done? thou'st 'scaped
The raging lion, to wrestle with a dragon,
He would have slain with a majestic gripe.
But this with venom; better had been thy fate
By him to fall, than thus, by such a hellhound.

div.stage: Enter Moor and soldiers, with Julianus.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Bring forth that traitor, same that lustful whore.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What wilt thou monster?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Any thing that's monstrous.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Reward a traitor.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Traitor?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Be thine own judge,
What art thou but thy Kings, and kingdom's ruin?
Was it thy hopes, that ever I should trust thee?
Traitors are poisoned arrows drawn toth' head.
Which we shoot home at mischief; being struck dead,
Then let the arrow be consumed in fire.
Hast not betrayed thy King and country basely

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: For thee (Ingrateful, villainous Moor) I have,
I have deserved to die, but not by thee,
And I beseech thee, bloody tyrant, hasten
My punishment.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: That boon is easily g 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis now full glory to thee, to strike h 〈…〉
Set the black character of death upon 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
give me a sentence horrid as thyself art,
Speak in thy barbarous language, thy last doom,
A tyrant's axe sends me to a ●●●st home.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Pluck out his eyes, and her exclaiming tongue,
She shall in silent sorrow then lead him,
Her eyes shall be his stars.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O spare her tyrant.
By her offence and wrong thou hast aspired,
Then tread not on her virtues, 〈◊〉 enough
That I do suffer for the good 〈◊〉 I did
To set thy 〈…〉 above my head:
O spare my child.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Entreat for me? forbear sir,
Either be you dumb or let him not hear,
I shall have mental 〈…〉 for heaven,
Fuller effectual than this tongue 〈◊〉 〈◊〉.
And for the author of my 〈◊〉 and 〈◊〉,
I shall have 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O justice, justice, thou that fill'st the throne
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 justice 〈…〉.
Give me thy sharpest 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Against 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Myself the 〈…〉 〈◊〉.

div.stage: Enter a 〈…〉 w 〈…〉 ed, with Dionisia sin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and see, here's 〈◊〉
A 〈…〉 ghost! murdered by me, 〈…〉

sp.speaker: A 〈…〉.
sp.l: To kill my friend, (My 〈…〉 friend) 〈◊〉 〈◊〉.
Thou strangledst l 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O my hard 〈◊〉
my aim, was full at thee.

sp.speaker: Aut.
sp.l: End thy just hate,
For I am parting from thee; see those two
That wronged thee are both wounded to the death,
With grief she, I by poison lose my breath.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Forgive him, but spare not me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How came you wounded?
I clap my hands at this your tragedy,
My birth was base, but my revenge flew high.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: A noble girl, a lusty stout virago.

sp.speaker: Aut.
sp.l: Julianus, for a wrong done to his daughter,
(The fatal engine that hath beat down Spain)
Revolted from his King, and set that Moor up,
Who now insults, being but a captive then,
And cause in honest language I was just
In taxing this revolt of 〈◊〉,
He bid a soldier kill me, who re 〈…〉 king 〈◊〉,
He himself struck me; life was 〈◊〉 thus long,
But for the clensing of my conscience:
I feel death pangs, forgive me both, and all,
Let my soul 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 anybody full
With honour I got honor, 〈◊〉 my 〈◊〉 thrives,
Thus falls the wretched husband of two wives

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: So, here's 〈◊〉 of 〈…〉,
A wholesome example to all successors ▪
Let every wise man take heed of two 〈◊〉,
'Tis ●●o 〈…〉 of the 〈◊〉
Myself should break one of 〈…〉 hearts.
What should I call thee, widow, shall we marry one another now.
And beget chimaeras, I do not think
That ever any one husband 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
On us both 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Which should supply the place of 〈◊〉 in 〈◊〉,
Merely fantastical ▪ are thy 〈◊〉
Such feathered follies, idle giggloto 〈…〉 ▪
are these the rites due to a funeral?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why? hast never seen the sunshine of a rainy day?
Who does believe a widow's tears to be her heart's sorrow?
Are they not then better spared than derided?
Let me see then what thou dar'st do with wet eyes,
That I dare not answer with a smiling cheek?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What thou dar'st not second I dare do.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Begin, I'll pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Try me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus then I come to thee a 〈…〉;
Thou didst forsake me living, being 〈◊〉
I will enjoy thy monumental bed.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Ay, hast thou that resolution?
Methinks a woman (〈◊〉 I am) should not out do me,
I must die one day, and as good this day as another,
Whereabouts is my heart, I think all over my body,
I am all heart, and therefore cannot miss,
Some creatures die singing, why not I merrily,
Make me room a 〈…〉 and 〈◊〉,
We'll all tumble in one bed together,
I'll lie as close as she on thy left side,
And have as many kisses too, that's my bargain;
My sins are all upon thy conscience,
But I forgive thee, and 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 the clerk to't,
My soul will have 〈◊〉 passage, my body I bequeath
To thee Antonio, I am your wife,
And will come to bed to you, thus I make unready,
Thus I lie down, thus kiss, and this embrace
I'll ever keep, I am 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 with play,
I needs must sleep for ever.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Excellent pastime

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis night with me for ever, where's this tyrant?
Turn me but to him, and from these darkened eyes
I shall discover his Cimmerian face,
For though all is dark, yet still that's visible,
And nothing else to me; see ran here vil 〈…〉,
Look what a bloody pageant thou hast made;
I borrow eyes to guide me of my child,
And her I'll lend a tongue to curse thee with.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thou laughest at misery.
'Tis well, thou givest a gr●●e 〈◊〉 my for 〈…〉,
Yet wherefore shouldst thou glory in't? this work
Is none of thine, 'tis heavens merciful justice,
For thou art but the 〈◊〉,
The master 〈◊〉, and th●se 〈◊〉
That did these bloody 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 upon't,
Thy second slaves, and yet I more deserve,
I was a traitor to my lawful King,
And though my w 〈…〉 〈…〉 cked on 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
I had no warrant signed for my revenge,
'Tis the people's sins that makes tyrants Kings,
And such was ●●ne for thee, now I obey,
But my affliction teaches 〈◊〉 too 〈◊〉
On bloody 〈…〉 her, 〈◊〉 up my 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Nor give thee living in captivity,
Thy body shall enjoy the general prison.
But thy soul set 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thou art good in th●●, and noble.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Nay it shall nobler be in the performance ,
Give him weapons, thou art a soldier,
And shalt end so; I'll be thy opposite ,
With odds of eyes, but not of arms, I vow,
If thy dark aim hit in my face, I'll stand,
And die with thee, if not, fall by my hand.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thoul't hurt my penitence, for I shall bless
All the ill deeds 〈◊〉 I have done for thee,
In this so noble end,

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: B● pr 〈…〉 then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: One thing more of 〈◊〉, be a prophet to me first,
For thou knowest what shall become of my poor Jacinta,
What end to her 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 end thou 〈◊〉 know it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O 〈…〉 it noble be, and honourable;
Her life has had 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 strokes of 〈◊〉;
O let her end be sp 〈…〉 g.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 shall be noble too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I 〈◊〉 for her that has no tongue to beg,
And what 〈…〉 my saint yielding breath,
Shall all be spent in blessings over thee:
Farewell Jacinta, take my latest blessing,
I know thy soul returns a thanks to me,
Make haste to overtake me, if thou beest stayed,
Think of Cleopatra and Brutus' wife,
There's many ways to end a weary life.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Come sir, I stand before you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thur I come,
Thy death I'll venture, but receive mine own,
So, I have my doom, and I have hit too.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Laughest then 〈◊〉 any 〈…〉 ed then.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: O bloody homicide, thou hast slain thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: False villain, hast thou then so mocked my woes,
To make me fatal butcher of my child?
W●● she the target to defend thy body?
Forgive me my Jacinta, 'twas in me
An innocent act of blood, but tyranny
In that black monster: 'tis not much ill,
Better my hand then a worse arm should spill
Thy guiltless life; what art thou going yet?
Thy warm blood cools, my sun begins to set,
Nature shrinks backward to her former forms,
Our souls climb stars, whilst these descend to worms.
See tyrant, from thy further strokes we fly,
Heaven do thy will, I will not cursing die.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: So, now we live beholding unto none
Upon this stair we do ascend our throne,
Give us our title.

sp.speaker: O 〈…〉.
sp.l: Long live Mulli 〈…〉 King of Spain.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Your silence it confirms, take hence their bodies,
Give them to Christians, and let them bestow
What ceremonious funerals they please.
We must pursue the flying r 〈…〉.
All must be ours, we'll have no kingdom sharer,
Let chroniclers write, here we begin our reign,
The first of Moors that e'er was King of Spain.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
